physDesc.p: This letter consists of 2 typed pages on carbon paper. The first page has damage to the entire right edge, in which it is crumbling off. The second page has some damage to the right edge as well. The second page has a heading above the dateline (Mr. Aldington - 2). Preceding the letter is a cheque for “Flint,” in which the front and back are scanned.

div.p: Your letter of August 26th was very pleasant to get. My secretary did make a mistake and forgot to enclose Flint's cheque, which you will find in this letter. I am sorry for the blunder. We have all been very bust with Mrs. Ayscough's and my book of Chinese translations, and I suppose that this draft got left out somehow.
I am sorry about what you tell me of Flint, but perhaps he is only changing his direction and becoming more interesting in his real work than in the literary part of his life.
I feel much better after this last operation, and have every hope of going to England next Spring.

Your letter is anything but cheerful. What is the matter with Eliot? I have no idea he was ill. At least, however, England does give pensions to her own young writers, and there are no such things of the kind here, except a few personal prizes which individuals manage, and there are only about two of those.

I hear quite constantly from Lawrence. He is getting a large public here in America. How scattered all the contributors to our anthology are, and how diversely we are all developing! But that is as it should be, I think. If we were not bigger than our theories, we should not be of much use.

I do not wonder that you found Harriet Monroe difficult to work with. I find her the same. I do not think you will miss much by not writing for “Poetry.” Its influence is not great. I suppose you are still working on the “Times,” are you not? You do not mention it in your letter.

This is a short note and, I fear, a dull one, because, after three
weeks of hard work getting our Chinese book into the press, I am trying to do up my belated mail, so I will not write more at the moment.
